text: hi everyone today I will make mantiene
or Rose next cake
it's a traditional cake originated from
Southwest in Vietnam it's used to be a
very popular strict snack on the streets
of Saigon but over the past few years
the vendors selling these cakes have
gradually disappeared and it's now very
difficult to fire a place that sells
these cakes I'm not sure whether it's
because people now before eating Western
cakes or because more vendors just quit
selling these cakes due to low profits
anyway I was lucky enough to have run
into this vendor during my visit to
Saigon earlier this year and I thought
it would be a real pity if it's become
extinct one day because too many
Vietnamese is still a very special snack
they're associated with many childhood
memories when I saw her making the cakes
it's just like watching magic she just
pour the batter into a wok of hot oil
and then it just magically formed into a
shape of a bus nest it's very crispy
around the rim and then it just has a
little killed hum in the center how cool
is that I asked her for the secrets and
she told me that it's because of the wok
that she was using of course she didn't
tell me what was in the batter so I have
to figure it out myself it's a little
oily and must say but it tastes really
good that was me tasting business cake
on the streets of Saigon wearing helmet
and a mask like everybody else does even
though I don't have the same walk at the
vendor I really want to give this cake a
try so let's revive this cake together
the ingredients are very simple you just
need rice flour tapioca starch coconut
milk some baking soda sugar and vanilla
in a large bowl combine one cup of
coconut milk 1/2 a cup water and about 4
to 6 tbsp of sugar depending on your
taste and then stir well to dissolve you
can warm it up 30 seconds in the
microwave I'll put it in a tray of hot
water so that the sugar can dissolve
faster also add a pinch of salt and some
vanilla if you like in a separate bowl
combine half a cup tapioca starch and 1
and 1/2 cup rice flour make sure you use
plain white rice flour normally comes in
blue package and not the glutinous rice
flour which normally comes in a green
package make a hole in the middle and
pour in the coconut in your mixture stir
really well to get a smooth batter to
that we can add the quarter teaspoon
baking soda
this is what pushes the cake to float to
the surface when we deep-fry against our
really well to make sure that there's no
lump let the batter rest for about three
to five hours now the more tricky part
of making this cake is to control the
temperature of the oil fill the wok with
at least 2 inches of vegetable oil to
test if the oil is hot enough stand a
wooden chopstick in the center if a few
bubbles pop up like this is not hot
enough if it bubbles steadily like this
is now ready to deep fry it should be a
sore out 180 degrees Celsius or 360
Fahrenheit if the oil bubbles very very
vigorously most likely you're going to
burn your cake another way to test the
oil temperature is to ask a few drops of
the butter into the hot oil if it's turn
brown within 60 seconds is ready before
frying give the batter a really good
stir you a shallow ladle to scoop the
butter lower the later just above the
oil level and quickly pour into the
center of the wok make sure you use a
nonstick wok for this within one or two
seconds the cake will float to the
surface
the edges will turn brown within a few
minutes it's just really exciting to see
how the hum is formed in the middle of
the cake flip it over and fry the other
side for just a few more seconds look at
this my cute little birds nest then put
it on the rack so that the oil can drip
off repeat until you finish the pattern
just fry one cake at a time so that it
has room to expand and pour the batter
into the center of the wok so that the
home can be formed so now you know
Plus nest cake is not made from birth
next but it's called at wages because it
has a shape of birth next after resting
the cakes on the rack for a few minutes
you can check it out and place on
kitchen towel to remove the excess oil
this is our beautiful bust next cake is
crispy around the rim and has a knife
hump in the center and the best thing is
when you break the cake in half you will
see a nice honeycomb texture inside the
home this part will taste a little chewy
which is really nice
the cake is fragrant slightly sweet and
has a nice coconut paste this is how I
recycle the oil place a mesh strainer on
top of the bowl and lie it with a piece
of kitchen paper make sure the ball and
the strainer is completely dry if
there's any water the organiz glass next
time you use it the paper towel will
catch all the crumbs and the dregs you
can do this one or two times to refine
the oil you can reuse the oil many times
until it looks or smells bad
that's it for today I hope you liked it
don't forget to thumbs up and subscribe
thank you for watching bye
you
